Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Grant \Grant\ (gr[.a]nt), v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Granted}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Granting}.] [OE. graunten, granten, OF. graanter, craanter, creanter, to promise, yield, LL. creantare to promise, assure, for (assumed LL.) credentare to make believe, fr. L. credens, p. pr. of credere to believe. See {Creed}, {Credit}.] 1. To give over; to make conveyance of; to give the possession or title of; to convey; -- usually in answer to petition. [1913 Webster]
Grant me the place of this threshing floor. --1 Chron. xxi. 22. [1913 Webster]
2. To bestow or confer, with or without compensation, particularly in answer to prayer or request; to give. [1913 Webster]
Wherefore did God grant me my request. --Milton. [1913 Webster]
3. To admit as true what is not yet satisfactorily proved; to yield belief to; to allow; to yield; to concede. [1913 Webster]
Grant that the Fates have firmed by their decree. --Dryden.
Syn: Syn.-- To give; confer; bestow; convey; transfer; admit; allow; concede. See {Give}. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
granted \granted\ adj. 1. Given. [WordNet 1.5]
2. (Logic, Rhetoric) Acknowledged or assumed as a supposition.
Syn: given. [WordNet 1.5]
granted adj 1: acknowledged as a supposition; "given the engine's condition, it is a wonder that it started" [syn: {given}] 2: given as a grant; "the special funds granted for his research project"
